page_analysis.text_content:
Roofed porches on the 1st floor

How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

Fig 5 Roofed 1st floor porch

Step 1: Determine the perimeter of the porch and divide it into segments that will allow a comparison of closed and open segments.

The perimeter of the porch in Fig 5 is shown below. It is the sum of segments A through G. It is 70 linear feet.

visual_elements.description: A 3D isometric illustration of a house showing a roofed 1st floor porch wrapping around the front and side of the house. The porch has columns and a roof structure visible.
visual_elements.location: left side, middle of the page

visual_elements.description: A floor plan layout of the porch with labeled segments A through G along the perimeter. Dimensions are marked for each segment: A = 3', B = 8', C = 10', D = 7', E = 14', F = 24', G = 4'. The diagram shows the porch perimeter with arrows indicating segment lengths and a total perimeter of 70 linear feet.
visual_elements.location: right side, middle of the page

subheadings: How to determine if a porch is at least 50% open (using Fig 5 as an example)

additional_notes: Page number 8 at bottom left corner
No handwritten annotations, stamps, or markings detected
Text and images are clear and legible
cross_references: Reference to Fig 5 within the page
